head.headtext: Affirmative defenses in criminal cases—Burden-shifting and due process

para.paratext: Due to problems raised by federal courts' application of the U.S. Constitution, the usual rules as to affirmative defenses in criminal cases have largely disappeared. Only a few true affirmative defenses remain.

Due process requires that the prosecution prove beyond a reasonable doubt every fact necessary to constitute the crime charged.[1] There is a due process problem when a matter is treated as an affirmative defense, by statute or decision, and the burden is shifted to a criminal defendant.

In 1975, Maine law provided that, if the prosecution proved a felonious homicide, the burden shifted to the defendant to prove that he acted in the heat of passion on sudden provocation in order for him to receive the lesser penalty prescribed for manslaughter. In Mullaney v. Wilbur,[2] the United States Supreme Court held that placing this burden on the criminal defendant violated due process.

Two years later, the court explained the Mullaney decision in Patterson v. New York,[3] which involved a New York statute that did not include malice aforethought as an element of second-degree murder. The defendant's claim that he acted “under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance” in order to reduce the offense to manslaughter was an affirmative defense. Under the Maine statute in Mullaney, malice aforethought was an element of murder and the “heat of passion” defense would negate that element. The Court distinguished the two statutes and held in Patterson that a proper affirmative defense was created which gave the defendant the burden of persuasion. As the Court said, “Proof of the nonexistence of all affirmative defenses has never been constitutionally required; and we perceive no reason to fashion such a rule in this case and apply it to the statutory defense at issue here.” The Court also said that this view did not permit the reallocating of burdens by labeling statutory elements of crimes as affirmative defenses.

The cases of Sandstrom v. Montana[4] and County Court of Ulster County, N.Y. v. Allen[5] held that a presumption that was conclusive or shifted the burden of persuasion to the defendant in a criminal case would be invalid. A jury charge that they must find a fact from a mandatory presumption would have the effect of directing at least part of the verdict against the defendant. The trial judge must exercise caution in his jury charge and any presumption or “permissive inference” against the defendant may be rebutted. Otherwise, the charge would be error.[6] The result was that where no true affirmative defenses involved and a presumption may have its usual effect of shifting the burden of producing evidence to the defendant.

The courts reviewing jury charges post-Sandstrom have found some proper[7] and others burden shifting.[8] Georgia courts follow the cautions identified in Mullaney, Patterson, and Sandstrom.[9] It is clear that any jury charge arising from an affirmative defense or presumption that shifts the burden of persuasion regarding innocence on the defendant violates his constitutional right to due process.[10] In a criminal case, the state need not disprove an affirmative defense in its indictment.[11] An affirmative defense is a matter for the defendant to raise. The burden of proof then shifts to the state to disprove the affirmative defense beyond a reasonable doubt.[12]

The Georgia Court of Appeals clearly addressed the issue of a jury charge arising from an affirmative defense or presumption that shifts the burden of persuasion regarding innocence in State v. Moore[13] by holding that a charge that “coercion” is an affirmative defense, which requires the defendant to carry the burden of persuasion by a preponderance of the evidence, was error under Mullaney. The Georgia Supreme Court reversed this holding, but adopted a new rule for the future:

After careful consideration this court has concluded that the trial courts would welcome a simple straightforward rule which can be applied easily and would lessen the possibility of error. Also we are of the opinion that the desirability of uniformity in jury instructions outweighs adherence to a rule which is of doubtful value, probably makes overly nice legal distinctions which are difficult for many juries to follow, and so far as can be discerned has little, if any, influence upon verdicts reached in particular criminal cases. Therefore we hold that henceforth charges which place any burden of persuasion upon the defendant in criminal cases shall not be given and such charges will be deemed erroneous and subject to reversal, absent harmless error and invited error.[14]

Subsequently, some courts extended this rule by placing an affirmative duty upon the trial court to expressly charge the jury that the state, rather than the defendant, bears the burden of persuasion as to a particular element.

In Sheppard v. State,[15] a defendant who presented evidence of self-defense requested a jury charge that the state had the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant did not act in self-defense. The Georgia Court of Appeals held that it was error not to give the requested charge.[16]

The burden of persuasion is on the state to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused did not act in self-defense.[17] However, the result was different in Bruce v. Smith,[18] where a defendant asserted the affirmative defense of “accident” to a felony murder charge. The Georgia Supreme Court held that it is sufficient to instruct the jury that “the defendant was presumed innocent, the state had the burden of proving every element of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt, the intent to commit the crime was an essential element that the state had to prove, the burden of proof remained with the state and never shifted to the defendant, and the jury had a duty to acquit if the evidence showed the incident occurred as a result of misfortune or accident.”[19] The Georgia Code also establishes “accident”[20] and “entrapment”[21] as affirmative defenses in criminal cases. Courts have held that “the equal access rule,” as it applies in the criminal context, is an evidentiary showing that a someone other than the defendant had equal access to contraband found in an automobile and is not an affirmative defense for which the burden to disprove falls on the state.[22]

In Wyatt v. State,[23] the Georgia Supreme Court considered the question of whether a prosecutor's aggressive cross examination improperly shifted the burden of persuasion to the defendant. The court concluded that the trial court's jury charges complied with Moore and did not improperly shift the burden of persuasion to the defendant, but that the “questioning was improper because it asked appellant what evidence he could introduce in his own defense, thereby implying that appellant carried some burden to disprove the state's charges against him, when the law is absolutely clear that a criminal defendant carries no burden of proof or persuasion whatsoever.”[24] The court did not declare a mistrial because the trial court explained, in the jury's presence that the line of questioning being pursued was improper, and the trial court's jury charge made it abundantly clear that the state carried all burdens of proof and persuasion regarding the charges against defendant and that defendant carried no burden of proof or persuasion to disprove those charges.[25]

Mullaney v. Wilbur, 421 U.S. 684, 95 S. Ct. 1881, 44 L. Ed. 2d 508 (1975); Sandstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S. 510, 99 S. Ct. 2450, 61 L. Ed. 2d 39 (1979) (conclusive presumption or a presumption shifting the burden of persuasion to the defendant in a criminal case would be invalid).
Patterson v. New York, 432 U.S. 197, 97 S. Ct. 2319, 53 L. Ed. 2d 281 (1977); Strong v. State, 246 Ga. 612, 272 S.E.2d 281 (1980).
Sandstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S. 510, 99 S. Ct. 2450, 61 L. Ed. 2d 39 (1979).

In Connecticut v. Johnson, 460 U.S. 73, 103 S. Ct. 969, 74 L. Ed. 2d 823 (1983), the Court granted certiorari to resolve a conflict as to whether or not a charge that violated the Sandstrom rule could be harmless error under Chapman v. California, 386 U.S. 18, 87 S. Ct. 824, 17 L. Ed. 2d 705, 24 A.L.R.3d 1065 (1967). Unfortunately, the conflict was not resolved in a 4-1-4 opinion. The concurring justice joined in affirming the Connecticut court since he said that there was no federal question. The plurality may have said that the harmless error rule could apply in rare situations, but the dissent stated that they had not and that they had greatly limited the rule of the Chapman case.

In Rose v. Clark, 478 U.S. 570, 106 S. Ct. 3101, 92 L. Ed. 2d 460 (1986), the court held that the harmless error rule could be applied to charges that were invalid under Sandstrom, Ulster County, and Francis v. Franklin. The case was remanded for a determination by the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit as to whether the error in the case was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.

Rose v. Clark was applied in two cases where the error was found to be harmless: Lewis v. State, 180 Ga. App. 890, 351 S.E.2d 100 (1986), and Williams v. State, 180 Ga. App. 893, 350 S.E.2d 768 (1986).

Before the decision in Rose v. Clark, the Georgia Supreme Court had applied the harmless error rule in Williams v. Kemp, 255 Ga. 380, 338 S.E.2d 669 (1986), in a long, excellent opinion that considered most of the federal cases.
County Court of Ulster County, N. Y. v. Allen, 442 U.S. 140, 99 S. Ct. 2213, 60 L. Ed. 2d 777 (1979).
Lane v. State, 153 Ga. App. 101, 264 S.E.2d 569 (1980); Hosch v. State, 246 Ga. 417, 271 S.E.2d 817 (1980) (error).

Also, should not state in charge: “The law presumes ….” But in Wells v. State, 247 Ga. 792, 279 S.E.2d 213 (1981), the court said that the disapproval in the Hosch case did not automatically lead to reversal, since the entire charge must be examined and the entire charge in this case was not error. In Rose v. State, 249 Ga. 628, 292 S.E.2d 678 (1982), citing Wells v. State, the court said: “nonetheless, we disapprove and will continue to disapprove the practice of casting criminal jury instructions in terms of ‘presumptions.’” A trial judge would be well advised to use the word “inference” instead of “presumption.”
The admonition of the Rose case was repeated in the case of Rivers v. State, 250 Ga. 303, 298 S.E.2d 1 (1982).
See Wilson v. Jones, 251 Ga. 23, 302 S.E.2d 546 (1983); Trenor v. State, 252 Ga. 264, 313 S.E.2d 482 (1984) (charge that “law would presume malice and intent to kill” error).

In House v. State, 252 Ga. 409, 314 S.E.2d 195 (1984), the court held that the charge as to intent was not burden shifting, but again said that the charge suggested in Hosch v. State and Trenor v. State would have been better.

See Whisenhunt v. State, 152 Ga. App. 829, 264 S.E.2d 271 (1979); Maxwell v. State, 152 Ga. App. 776, 264 S.E.2d 254 (1979); Dix v. State, 153 Ga. App. 868, 267 S.E.2d 293 (1980); Rittenberry v. State, 155 Ga. App. 213, 270 S.E.2d 379 (1980); Evans v. State, 156 Ga. App. 162, 275 S.E.2d 341 (1980); Peterson v. State, 158 Ga. App. 195, 279 S.E.2d 493 (1981).

In Williamson v. State, 248 Ga. 47, 281 S.E.2d 512 (1981), the Court made an extensive and exhaustive review of the federal cases in this area. The Court held that the inference of the theft was proper and that the charge given as to that inference was not burden shifting.
See Williams v. State, 159 Ga. App. 865, 285 S.E.2d 597 (1981); Lett v. State, 160 Ga. App. 476, 287 S.E.2d 384 (1981); Johnson v. State, 249 Ga. 621, 292 S.E.2d 696 (1982).

Collins v. Francis, 728 F.2d 1322, 15 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 404 (11th Cir. 1984), held that the charge on intent, even if burden shifting, was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt under the facts. Following the 11th Circuit, Parker v. Pace, 254 Ga. 634, 331 S.E.2d 546 (1985), held that a charge on the presumption of malice was error, but that the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. These cases could not rely on Rose v. Clark, 478 U.S. 570, 106 S. Ct. 3101, 92 L. Ed. 2d 460 (1986).

In Franklin v. State, 245 Ga. 141, 154, 263 S.E.2d 666 (1980), the Georgia Supreme Court held that the charge on intent did not violate the rule of Sandstrom v. Montana. After the usual federal habeas corpus route, over five years later, in the usual 5-4 decision, the Supreme Court of Francis v. Franklin, 471 U.S. 307, 105 S. Ct. 1965, 85 L. Ed. 2d 344 (1985), held that the charge did violate Sandstrom v. Montana. The dissent pointed out that the majority had picked out one or two sentences from several pages of instructions to find a violation and that if the charge as a whole were considered, there was no violation. As stated by Justice Rehnquist: “I do not believe that the Court must inject itself this far into the state criminal process to protect the fundamental rights of criminal defendants.”

But see Bruce v. Smith, 274 Ga. 432, 434, 553 S.E.2d 808 (2001) (“A review of [Georgia Supreme Court] decisions on the burden of proof related to affirmative defenses in criminal cases shows that the issue is a difficult one that has challenged [the court] for three decades.”).
Budhani v. State, 2019 WL 2708359 (Ga. 2019).
Klemetti v. State, 334 Ga. App. 513, 780 S.E.2d 346 (2015); State v. Alvarez, 299 Ga. 213, 790 S.E.2d 66 (2016); Budhani v. State, 2019 WL 2708359 (Ga. 2019).

State v. Moore, 237 Ga. 269, 270, 227 S.E.2d 241 (1976). The court then went on to point out that the “usual charges on presumptions are not considered ‘burden shifting’ charges, nor are charges that such presumptions may be rebutted.” They are now so-considered, however.

See Francis v. Franklin, 471 U.S. 307, 105 S. Ct. 1965, 85 L. Ed. 2d 344 (1985), wherein the United States Supreme Court held that including such a presumption in a jury charge improperly shifts the burden of proof to the defendant in a criminal case.
Shepperd v. State, 170 Ga. App. 286, 316 S.E.2d 785 (1984).
Shepperd v. State, 170 Ga. App. 286, 316 S.E.2d 785 (1984).
Jordan v. State, 173 Ga. App. 395, 326 S.E.2d 574 (1985).

Accident is an affirmative defense, “whereby it must be established a defendant was not acting with criminal intent, was not engaged in a criminal scheme, and was not criminally negligent, i.e., did not act in a manner showing an utter disregard for the safety of others who might reasonably be expected to be injured thereby.” Mayberry v. State, 281 Ga. 144, 635 S.E.2d 736 (2006) (citing Davis v. State, 269 Ga. 276, 496 S.E.2d 699 (1998)).
See O.C.G.A. § 16-3-25; Lightsey v. State, 289 Ga. App. 181, 656 S.E.2d 852 (2008).

In State v. Jones, 297 Ga. 156, 773 S.E.2d 170 (2015), the Supreme Court held that it was not error for the trial court to allow evidence of a prior DUI because the evidence was admissible to prove that he knew he was driving less safe or with an illegal blood alcohol level and as such the evidence was consistent and only added to the state's burden of proof.
